properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of daytime high temperatures near 29 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 14 degrees Celsius continues today. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-22T02:55:40-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A forest fire in the Manicouagan region is currently producing a smoke plume affecting Lac Saint-Jean this evening. These conditions are expected to improve tonight or tomorrow morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-21T18:37:15-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The heat wave will continue this weekend and into the week. Time span: Sunday and into the new week. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 16 inland with cooler temperatures along the coast. Maximum Temperature Sunday (central and west): 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37). Locations: inland areas of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Temperatures will be much lower over Cape Breton. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-21T16:18:32-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The heat wave will continue into the week. Time span: today and into the new week. Maximum temperatures today: 30 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 33 to 39). Maximum temperatures on Monday 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 35 to 39). Locations: New Brunswick. Remarks: Hot and humid conditions will continue or redevelop today and continue into mid week for most of New Brunswick. The Fundy coast, however, should cool tonight and stay below warning criteria for the remainder of the week. We anticipate that the heat warning for these regions will end by this evening. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of fine particulates are expected and will result in poor air quality. Smoke from a peat fire in the Kamouraska area is causing poor air quality. The poor air quality will persist through midday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will continue streaming into the regions from the south. Border line heat warning criteria is expected to be reached again today. A cold front will move through Monday to bring an end to the heat. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The heat wave will continue, but with cool temperatures bringing some relief tonight. Time span: today and into the new week. Maximum temperature today: 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34). Minimum temperatures tonight: 14 Celsuis with cooler temperatures in low lying areas. Maximum Temperature Monday: 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34). Locations: inland areas of western Nova Scotia, Annapolis Valley, and the Tri-County area. Remarks: Another run of very warm days is on it's way; however, temperatures tonight will cool to below heat warning criteria and provide some relief for the overnight hours. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-22T05:54:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-21T13:55:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1157208117.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke is causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Smoke is expected or occurring. High air pollution is expected this evening and tomorrow due to forest fire smoke. Smoke plumes from forest fires in the Manicouagan area could affect neighbouring areas. Air quality could deteriorate should the smoke go down to ground level. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If your home is not air-conditioned, be sure the house doesn't get too warm when doors and windows are closed to keep out smoke. Exposure to too much heat can also result in illness. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-21T16:30:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-21T01:11:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2431620250.2020
Area: Chibougamau, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will continue streaming into the regions from the south. Border line heat warning criteria is expected to be reached again today. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can cause the air quality health index to approach the high risk category. Increased cloud cover will reduce maximum temperatures to below warning criteria for Monday. It will remain humid until a cold front arrives Tuesday. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
